name: NPR
text:
RT @HiddenBrain: Some advice on how to live a good life, drawn from the ancient Stoics:

1. Do what you can, with what you’ve got, where you are.

name: NPR
text:
RT @laurelwamsley: Today, Tyson Foods fired 7 managers at its pork plant in Waterloo, Iowa, over a betting ring guessing how many workers would get the virus. 

More than 1,000 at the plant were infected. Six died.

My story for @NPR:

https://t.co/mSlf37FI5W

name: NPR
text: RT @NinaTotenberg: Colleges and Universities make billions from big time sports. #SCOTUS considers whether they are violating antitrust laws by banning compensation for these players https://t.co/EypFRl9puh

name: NPR
text:
The philanthropist MacKenzie Scott says she has donated more than $4 billion in the last 4 months to organizations that fulfill basic needs for those struggling during the pandemic and to others targeting systemic inequities.
https://t.co/wK1CwlkLNz

name: NPR
text: RT @annkpowers: I found it really hard to write this year, until I spent time reflecting on pandemic times as a whole. Worked hard on this essay, it's long, it's personal, hope you can carve out some time to read it https://t.co/76SyW6BwxN

name: NPR
text:
UC Irvine and the California prison system have reached a deal to create the first University of California bachelor’s degree program behind bars. (@KQED)
https://t.co/pnzKoRMIoP

name: NPR
text:
☃️❄️ "People just want something to feel good about."

Homebound by the pandemic and longing for something festive, many families are turning their holiday decorations way, way up.
https://t.co/3JrwE157AT

name: NPR
text:
Tyson Foods has fired 7 managers at an Iowa pork plant after investigating allegations they bet on how many workers would get sick from the coronavirus. 

Over 1,0000 employees there have been infected. At least 6 have died.
 https://t.co/2vupKu3Nup

name: NPR
text:
Tyson Foods has fired 7 managers at an Iowa pork plant after investigating allegations they bet on how many workers would get sick from the coronavirus. 

Over 1,000 employees there have been infected. At least 6 have died.
https://t.co/pO3ze6ybSw

name: NPR
text: Note: A previous tweet erroneously said over 1,0000 employees have been infected. It should have said over 1,000.

name: NPR
text:
Scores of private charitable foundations — set up by some of the U.S.'s wealthiest people — received money from the Paycheck Protection Program. 

Among them: the Walt Disney Family Foundation and a foundation affiliated with billionaire Warren Buffett.
https://t.co/8IfKZJhggO

name: NPR
text:
The Supreme Court will review a case testing whether the NCAA's limits on compensation for student-athletes violate the nation's antitrust laws. The outcome could have major implications for college athletics.
https://t.co/CDf9RnAgpi

name: NPR
text:
The FDA has authorized health workers to use extra doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine found in some vials that have been distributed throughout the U.S. this week.
https://t.co/fhCaHuuoCY

name: NPR
text: Russian agents trailed opposition leader Alexei Navalny for years — and were nearby just before an attack with a deadly nerve agent almost killed him in August, an investigation by the research group Bellingcat finds. https://t.co/SAIlbxQlTK

name: NPR
text:
Twitter says it will swiftly remove debunked claims about COVID-19 vaccinations starting next week. 
https://t.co/j0W2XEbNwP

name: NPR
text:
Pulse oximeters, which measure oxygen in the blood, can sometimes give misleading readings for patients with dark skin, a new report finds. The devices are used in COVID-19 treatment.
https://t.co/mPyNs2K9qn

name: NPR
text:
"I do feel that I sing the basics of American music: country, gospel and the blues. I think I'm the epitome of all of that. And not only when you hear me, but when you see me, too."  

More than a symbol, Charley Pride was a masterful country artist. https://t.co/ZkKAuhsTOZ

name: NPR
text: After nearly two decades of maintaining his innocence, Myon Burrell was released from prison by Minnesota officials. The move comes after investigative journalists tore apart authorities' handling of the case, which sent Burrell to prison for murder at 16. https://t.co/Vst5ye7mW0

name: NPR
text:
Directly contradicting international health guidance about how the coronavirus is typically transmitted, Chinese officials say a flurry of recent cases stems from workers who had contact with imported food packaging.

Scientists call the theory “unlikely.” https://t.co/SIshXuk7RM

name: NPR
text:
As chief of critical care at a Houston hospital, Dr. Joseph Varon is at the center of managing care for patients with the coronavirus.

He's worked every day for the last 272 days.

"No days off," he told NPR. https://t.co/dtPbFuOc2S

name: NPR
text:
"I have people that don't believe the virus is real; they feel like it's a government conspiracy," one LA resident says. "These are friends that I've known since middle school. One friend, I was in her wedding."
https://t.co/xmmSP6qA2u

name: NPR
text: The Berggruen Prize for Philosophy and Culture gives $1 million for "new thinking to help society evolve." Dr. Paul Farmer brings modern medical care to those in need, so while he wasn't expecting a philosophy prize, he'll put the money to good use. https://t.co/93g4H9jFbE

name: NPR
text:
A private charitable foundation linked to billionaire Warren Buffett got federal funding from the Paycheck Protection Program. 

It wasn't the only one. 

NPR identified at least 120 tax-exempt foundations that received more than $7.5 million in PPP money.
https://t.co/0iZsIn1J1q
